comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Hi Beachcomber - that sounds about right! This article mentions the vessel's arrival in Sydney that year.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I think the 'Orsova' was arriving in Sydney "shortly after dawn" on Monday 19/4/1954. Berthed at Wharf 13 Pyrmont, hence she is heading under the Bridge. Kirribilli Ferry Wharf at right. Evidently the "distinctive "Welsh Hat" funnel is specially designed to keep the deck clear of smut." [sic!] Also ... "As fastest ship In the trade, it is entitled to carry a golden rooster at the masthead to show it is "cock o' the sea", but it is the only big liner in the Australian trade that has no mast." - SMH 20/4/1954 p.4 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/18421341 . This must have been one of Samuel J. Hood's last photographs.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Hood died in 1953, so perhaps this was taken by his son Ted, or a representative from the studio. Interesting...
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 38535102@N04
comment._content: She is definitely is the Orsova. l sailed on her as a deckhand throughout 1968.
